question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech.
The soldier said to his fellow soldiers, "I have buried our brave comrade here.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-2 (20 Jan))
option_1: The soldier told us that I had buried their brave comrade here.
option_2: The soldier told his fellow soldiers that I had buried our brave comrade there.
option_3: The soldier told us that he had buried our brave comrade there.
option_4: The soldier told his fellow soldiers that he had buried their brave comrade there.
solution:
Explanation:

Correct because it follows all the necessary shifts:

  • "I" changes to "he."

  • "Our" changes to "their."

  • "Have buried" changes to "had buried."

  • "Here" changes to "there."

The most appropriate option to express the given sentence in reported speech is:

The soldier told his fellow soldiers that he had buried their brave comrade there.

Thus, Option 4 is the correct conversion into reported speech.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech.
He said, "I shall need a copy of the documents."

(SSC CGL 2024 T-2 (20 Jan))
option_1: He said that he will need a copy of the documents.
option_2: He said that he is going to need a copy of the document.
option_3: He said that he would need a copy of the documents.
option_4: He said that he shall need a copy of the document.
solution:
Explanation:

In indirect speech, when reporting statements about future actions, the future tense in direct speech typically changes to the conditional tense in indirect speech. Therefore, "shall need" becomes "would need." Additionally, the reporting verb "said" is followed by "that" to introduce the reported speech.

Direct Speech: "I shall need a copy of the documents."

Indirect Speech: He said that he would need a copy of the documents.

Thus, Option 3 is the right answer.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech.
Kanhaiya said to me, “Do you want to sing?”

(SSC CGL 2024 T-2 (20 Jan))
option_1: Kanhaiya said that whether I would sing.
option_2: Kanhaiya enquires if I want to sing.
option_3: Kanhaiya asked me if I wanted to sing.
option_4: Kanhaiya said that I would sing or not.
solution:
Explanation:

When converting a question into indirect speech, we follow these rules:

  • "Do you want" becomes "I wanted" (since it's a question in the present tense, it changes to past tense in reported speech).

  • The word "Do" is omitted in indirect speech.

  • The question mark is replaced with "if" or "whether".

  • The pronoun "you" changes to "I" based on the speaker.

Thus, the correct form would be "Kanhaiya asked me if I wanted to sing."

Thus, Option 3 is the right answer.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech.
'I am determined to publish my findings,' the scientist asserted confidently.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-2 (18 Jan))
option_1: The scientist confidently asserted that she would be determined to publish her findings.
option_2: The scientist confidently asserted that she is determined to publish her findings.
option_3: The scientist confidently asserted that she had determined to publish her findings.
option_4: The scientist confidently asserted that she was determined to publish her findings.
solution:
Explanation:

When converting direct speech to reported speech:

  • Tense shift: The present tense ("am determined") changes to the past tense ("was determined") because the reporting verb "asserted" is in the past tense.

  • Pronoun adjustment: "I" changes to "she" to reflect the subject in reported speech.

  • Logical consistency: The past tense aligns with standard rules for reported speech.

Correct answer: The scientist confidently asserted that she was determined to publish her findings.

Thus, Option 4 is the right answer.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech.

The teacher informed that the exam had been postponed.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-2 (18 Jan))
option_1: The teacher informed, “The exam has been postponed.”
option_2: The teacher informs, “The exam had been postponed.”
option_3: The teacher informs, “The exam has been postponed.”
option_4: The teacher informed, “The exam was being postponed.”
solution:
Explanation:

When converting indirect speech to direct speech, it's essential to maintain the original meaning and tense of the reported speech. In the given sentence, "The teacher informed that the exam had been postponed," the reporting verb "informed" is in the past tense, and the reported speech is in the past perfect tense ("had been postponed").

In direct speech, we quote the exact words spoken, so the sentence becomes:

The teacher informed, “The exam has been postponed.”

Here, the present perfect tense "has been postponed" is used to indicate that the exam is currently postponed at the time of speaking.

Thus, Option 1 is the right answer.

question:

option_2: The District Magistrate told the police, "Work all night and put an end to their riots."
option_3: The District Magistrate told the police, "Work all night to put an end these riots."
option_4: The District Magistrate told the police, "Work all night and put an end to these riots."
solution:
Explanation:

The sentence is correctly transformed into direct speech by quoting the District Magistrate's exact words.

The use of "these riots" is consistent with the context of the sentence.

The other options contain small errors in wording or phrasing.

The correct option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech is:

The District Magistrate told the police, "Work all night and put an end to these riots."

Thus, Option 4 is the right answer.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech.
He said, “I bought this book for my brother.”

(SSC CGL 2023 T-2 (26 Oct))
option_1: He said that he has bought this book for his brother.
option_2: He said that he buy this book for his brother.
option_3: He said that he bought this book for his brother.
option_4: He said that he had bought that book for his brother.
solution:
The correct answer is option d.

“He said that he had bought that book for his brother”

Direct speech ----------- indirect speech

Subject + verb (2nd form) + object ------------object + had (3rd form) + subject.

Hence, d is the most appropriate indirect speech.

question:

option_2: The principal say me, “You are in-charge of the admission cell.”

"The principal said to me, 'You are in-charge of the admission cell.'"

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech.

Joey said to the girl, “How are you doing?”

(SSC CGL 2022 T-2 (3 Mar))
option_1: Joey asked the girl how was she doing.
option_2: Joey asked the girl if she was doing fine.
option_3: Joey asked the girl how she was doing.
option_4: Joey asked the girl that how was she doing.
solution:
Rules for changing interrogative sentences from direct to indirect form.

‘said to’ - asked, questioned, inquired, or interrogated based on what is said in the sentence,

Question mark is changed to a full stop.

Interrogative form is not used in indirect speech. So, the helping verb is present after the subject.

If the questioned can be answered in yes/no, conjunction if/whether are used. If the question cannot be answered in yes/no, no conjunction is used.

Tenses and pronouns are changed according to the rules.

Considering the above rules, option c is correct.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech.

“So help me heaven!”, the man cried, “I shall never lie again.”

(SSC CGL 2022 T-2 (3 Mar))
option_1: The man called heaven and ordered to help him and see to it that she never lies again.
option_2: The man called upon heaven to witness his resolve that he would never lie again.
option_3: The man requested heaven to help him and see that he lie again.
option_4: The man cries out to heaven to help him not to lie again ever.
solution:
The given sentence is an exclamatory sentence. So,

‘cried’ will be changed into ‘called upon heaven’ because reporting speech has an exclamation.

‘to’ will be followed by the first form of the verb ‘witness’.

‘I’ will be changed to ‘he’.

‘shall’ will change to ‘would’

‘The man called upon heaven to witness his resolve that he would never lie again.’ So, the correct option is ‘b’.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech.

I warned Rita not to be late the next day.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-2 (6 Mar))
option_1: I warned Rita, “Not be late tomorrow”.
option_2: I warned to Rita, “Don’t be late tomorrow”.
option_3: I warned Rita, “Don’t be late tomorrow”.
option_4: I warning Rita, “Not be late tomorrow”.
solution:
While changing indirect speech to direct speech, the tense of the reporting verb and pronouns are changed. Punctuation marks at appropriate place and quotation marks are also added.

Here, in the given sentence,

Warned remains warned because the sentence is reported in the past. It will remain in the past in direct speech too.

Her changes to Rita

Not to be late changes to don’t be late

The next day changes to tomorrow.

All the above changes are present in option c only. So, c is the correct option.

question:

option_2: She asked about our meeting her partners next week.
option_3: She asked if we were meeting her partners next week.
option_4: She asked if we meet her partners next week.
solution:
Rules for changing interrogative sentences from direct to indirect form.

‘said to’ - asked, questioned, inquired, or interrogated based on what is said in the sentence,

Question mark is changed to a full stop.

Interrogative form is not used in indirect speech. So, the helping verb is present after the subject.

If the questioned can be answered in yes/no, conjunction if/whether are used. If the question cannot be answered in yes/no, no conjunction is used.

Tenses and pronouns are changed according to the rules

Present continuous tense will change into past continuous tense

Asked will remain asked.

Next week will change to the following week.

Considering all the above rules, option a is correct.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech.

Harry said that he would not be in town on Friday.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-2 (7 Mar))
option_1: Harry said, “I must not be in town on Friday”.
option_2: Harry said, “I can’t be in town on Friday”.
option_3: Harry said, “I will not be in town on Friday”.
option_4: Harry saying, “I will not be in town on Friday”.
solution:
Would cannot change to can or must. So, option a and b are incorrect.

Said will remain said and cannot change to saying. Hence, option c is the correct answer.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech.

The mother said that the kids were playing.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-2 (7 Mar))
option_1: The mother told, “The kids had been playing”.
option_2: The mother has said, “The kids were playing”.
option_3: The mother said, “The kids are playing”.
option_4: The mother said, “The kids have been playing”.
solution: When transformation is from indirect to direct speech, the past continuous tense is changed to present continuous tense. So, option a and option d cannot be correct. Option b is incorrect because of ‘has said’. So, option c is the correct answer.
